title.narrative: Civil society for enhanced democracy and human rights in Ukraine

description.narrative: To institutionally strengthen core civil society and human rights organisations at the regional level and to raise their capacity to contribute to more inclusive, democratic and rights-based governance.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation

title.narrative: CSDR output 1: Civil society organisations strengthened to promote democracy and foster participatory and result-driven Government-CSO dialogue at all levels in Ukraine.

1.1: Number of CSO Hubs specialised in democratisation - members of network.
1.3: CSO Hubs network strategy is developed in participatory way and adopted by members.
1.4. Number of CSO Hubs constituencies involved in the programme activities of CSO Hubs.
1.5.: Number of vulnerable groups representatives i.e. women. IDPs. Persons with Disabilities. minorities covered by the CSO Hubs activities.
1.6.: Number of successfully implemented CSO projects and initiatives

target.value: 1.1: Number of CSO Hubs specialised in democratisation - members of network. 1.3: CSO Hubs network strategy is developed in participatory way and adopted by members. 1.4. Number of CSO Hubs constituencies involved in the programme activities of CSO Hubs. 1.5.: Number of vulnerable groups representatives i.e. women. IDPs. Persons with Disabilities. minorities covered by the CSO Hubs activities. 1.6.: Number of successfully implemented CSO projects and initiatives

actual.value:
1.1: 5 CSO Hubs specialised on democratisation selected to become hubs; individual organizational plans for 2 years developed. implementation started
1.3.: Yes
1.4.: Number of CSOs constituencies involved in programme activities of the hubs have grown significantly 10.943 (3608 male; 7335 female due to increased number of organisations involved and the roll-out of their work at subnational level.
1.5.: 2.771 vulnerable men and women. including IPDs. people with disabilities. Roma. former combatants and people living in poverty were reached by the CSO hubs
1.6.: 0

title.narrative: CSDR output 2: Capacities of human rights actors enhanced to promote and defend human rights in Ukraine;

2.1.: Number of CSO hubs specialized in human rights – members of network.
2.2.: The extent to which the strategy of CSO hubs includes targeted interventions to involve and increase knowledge and skills of vulnerable groups.
2.3.: Number of CSO hubs applying HRBA in their programme work.
2.4.: Number of successfully implemented CSO projects and initiatives aimed at human rights promotion.
2.5.: Number of vulnerable groups representatives (i.e. women. IDPs. persons with disabilities. minorities) benefitting from implemented CSO projects and initiatives for HR promotion.
2.6. Number of alternative stakeholders’ reports to the international treaty bodies on various human rights issues prepared
2.7. Number of rights holders and duty bearers with skills and knowledge of civil society engagement in policy development and implementation

target.value: Capacities of human rights actors 2.1.: Number of CSO Hubs specialized in human rights – members of network. 2.2.: The extent to which the strategy of CSO Hubs includes targeted interventions to involve and increase knowledge and skills of vulnerable groups 2.3.: Number of CSO Hubs applying HRBA in their programme work 2.4.: Number of successfully implemented CSO projects and initiatives aimed at human rights promotion. including those with a special focus on vulnerable groups. 2.5.: Number of vulnerable groups representatives i.e. women. IDPs. persons with disabilities. minorities benefiting from the implemented CSO projects and initiatives aimed at human rights promotion. 2.6.: Number of alternative stakeholders reports to the international treaty bodies on various human rights issues prepared. 2.7. Number of rights holders and duty bearers with knowledge and skills in mechanisms of civil society engagements on policy development and implementation

actual.value:
2.1.: 4 CSO Hubs specialised on democratisation selected as hubs; individual organizational plans for 2 years developed. implementation started.
2.2.: 1 - very particular
2.3.: 9 CSO Hubs apply HRBA in their work; 3 CSO hubs network recognised by the Ministry of Justice as partner for human rights awareness raising. reaching out to citizens through 19 events on mechanisms of human rights protection.
2.4.: 4 projects and initiatives aimed at human rights promotion. including those with special focus on vulnerable groups. are in progress - focusing on CEDAW recommendations into policy and decision making at the subnational level. engaging young people in human rights activism and human rights violations in Donbas.
2.5.: 832 vulnerable. including rural women and youth. PwD. conflict-affected population. children from poor families. IPDs. LGBT representatives. Crimean Tatars and Romas reached by projects promoting HR.
2.6.: 6 reports.
2.7.: 113 duty beares; 170 right holders.

target.value: 2.1.: Number of CSO hubs specialized in human rights – members of network. 2.2.: The extent to which the strategy of CSO hubs includes targeted interventions to involve and increase knowledge and skills of vulnerable groups. 2.3.: Number of CSO hubs applying HRBA in their programme work. 2.4.: Number of successfully implemented CSO projects and initiatives aimed at human rights promotion. 2.5.: Number of vulnerable groups representatives (i.e. women. IDPs. persons with disabilities. minorities) benefitting from implemented CSO projects and initiatives for HR promotion. 2.6. Number of alternative stakeholders’ reports to the international treaty bodies on various human rights issues prepared 2.7. Number of rights holders and duty bearers with skilles and knowledge of civil society engagement in policy development and implementation

actual.value:
2.1.: 7 CSO Hubs
2.2.: 2 - partially
2.3.: 15 CSO Hubs.
2.4.: 6 projects and initiatives.
2.5.: 2.987 members
2.6.: 6 reports.
2.7.: 351 duty bearers; 982 right holders.

title.narrative: CSDR output 3: Enhanced civic youth engagement and youth participation in decision-making at all levels.

3.1.: Numbers of youth workers who have skills and knowledge to work and engage youth in civic activities.
3.2.: Number of young men and women that build skills in civic activism.
3.3.: Number of right holders and duty bearers with knowledge and skills on mechanisms of youth engagement in policy development and implementation for democracy and human rights
3.4. Number of engaged formal youth CSOs and non-formal youth groups advocating for the rights of vulnerable groups. i.e. women. IDPs PwD. minorities
3.5.: Number of successfully implemented youth initiatives aimed at enhanced democracy and human rights.

target.value:
3.1.: Numbers of youth workers who have skills and knowledge to work and engage youth in civic activities.
3.2.: Number of young men and women that build skills in civic activism.

title.narrative: Civil society has strong impact on the reform process in Ukraine, including in the regions, in the areas of democracy and human rights and they contributes to more inclusive, democratic and rights-based governance through enhanced capacity, better coordination and networking

target.value: 40 new policies and strategies at national and subnational levels developed and operationalised with active CSO participation (UNDP Programme Document Indicator).

title.narrative: CPAP Output 5: Capacity of national and local authorities and CSOs to promote human rights, access to justice and rule of law and to increase transparency and accountability developed.
CPAP Output 5: Capacity of national and local authorities and CSOs to promote human rights, access to justice and rule of law and to increase transparency and accountability developed.
